required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Retrospective Chart Review of Three Medifast Weight Control Centers
clinical_study.official_title: Use of the Medifast Meal Replacement Program for Weight Loss in Obese Patients: A Restrospective Chart Review of Three Medifast Weight Control Centers (MWCC)

brief_summary.textblock: The primary aim of this study is to to retrospectively evaluate the efficacy of the MWCC Jump Start (Medifast's 5 & 1) Plan on the following indices: weight loss, anthropometric changes, and reduction in common markers of coronary heart disease.

detailed_description.textblock: Portion-controlled meal replacements by themselves have been shown to be an effective weight control strategy in overweight and obese individuals. The addition of medical supervision has been shown to result in greater weight loss than meal replacements alone. MWCC provides this added support through individual weekly counseling sessions. Thus, the investigators plan to retrospectively evaluate the efficacy of the MWCC Jump Start (Medifast's 5 & 1) Plan on the following indices: weight loss, anthropometric changes, and reduction in common markers of coronary heart disease.

primary_outcome.time_frame: weeks 4, 12, 24 and final weight loss visit (average of 19.6 weeks)
primary_outcome.description: Weight loss (in pounds and percent weight loss) at weeks 4, 12, 24 and at final weight loss visit (average of 19.6 weeks).

primary_outcome.time_frame: weeks 4, 12, 24 and final weight loss visit (average of 19.6 weeks)
primary_outcome.description: changes in lean muscle mass, body fat mass, and body fat percent at weeks 4, 12, 24, and final weight loss visit(average of 19.6 weeks).

secondary_outcome.time_frame: weeks 4, 12, 24 and final weight loss visit (average of 19.6 weeks)
secondary_outcome.description: Compliance is measured by client attendance at weekly visits, consumption of meal replacements and dietary supplements, ketone testing, and completion of food journals

secondary_outcome.time_frame: weeks 4, 12, 24 and final weight loss visit (average of 19.6 weeks)
secondary_outcome.description: Retention of clients at specified time points (weeks 4, 12, 24 and final weight loss visit) and during the transition and weight maintenance phases of the MWCC weight management program

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Final weight loss visit (average of 19.6 weeks)
secondary_outcome.description: The percent of clients that achieve thier goal weight by their final weight loss visit(average of 19.6 weeks)

secondary_outcome.time_frame: weeks 4, 12, 24 and final weight loss visit (average of 19.6 weeks)
Following transition (up to 12 weeks) and maintenance (up to 52 weeks) phases of the program
weeks 4, 12, 24 and final weight loss visit (average of 19.6 weeks)
secondary_outcome.description: Improvements in diastolic and systolic blood pressure and pulse at weeks 4, 12, 24 and final weight loss visit (average of 19.6 weeks).

arm_group.description: This study will be a systematic retrospective chart review of clients participating in the Jump Start (5 & 1) Plan at three different MWCC locations in Texas during the years 2007 - 2010.

study_pop.textblock: This study was a systematic retrospective chart review of patients participating in the Jump Start (5 & 1) Plan at three different MWCC locations in Texas during the years 2007-2010.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Adult males and females aged 18-70
- Followed the Jump Start (5 & 1) Plan
- BMI â‰¥ 25
- Purchased a weight management program at the MWCC location in the last 3 years
- Signed patient health information consent form
Exclusion Criteria:
- On a plan other than the 5&1 (Jump Start)
- Completed initial consultation but did not participate further
- Program stopped due to client not getting baseline labs
- Program stopped due for medical reasons unrelated to the 5 & 1 (Jump Start) plan
- Currently an active participant at the MWCC
- No signed patient health information consent form or written request to revoke consent

reference.citation: Heymsfield SB, van Mierlo CA, van der Knaap HC, Heo M, Frier HI. Weight management using a meal replacement strategy: meta and pooling analysis from six studies. Int J Obes Relat Metab Disord. 2003 May;27(5):537-49.

Haddock CK, Poston WS, Foreyt JP, DiBartolomeo JJ, Warner PO. Effectiveness of Medifast supplements combined with obesity pharmacotherapy: a clinical program evaluation. Eat Weight Disord. 2008 Jun;13(2):95-101.
